newsitem.title: DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF CONGO: Troops break up opposition meeting in new Congo.
newsitem.headline: Troops break up opposition meeting in new Congo.

text.p: Soldiers broke up an opposition meeting in the Democratic Congo capital Kinshasa, arresting dozens of people, witnesses said on Saturday.

Troops entered the headquarters of the Union for Democracy and Social Progress (UDPS) in the Limete suburb, firing into the air to disperse a crowd of people attending a meeting of the youth wing of the party on Friday night, they said.
"Those who tried to put up resistance were taken away by the soldiers," one witness said.
There was no immediate report of any casualty.
UDPS supporters have clashed repeatedly since the exclusion of their leader, Etienne Tshisekedi, from President Laurent Kabila's new government.
Kabila toppled veteran dictator Mobutu Sese Seko in mid-May after a seven-month rebellion and renamed the former Zaire as the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
Tshisekedi led the civil campaign against Mobutu's 32-year rule and was widely expected to be named prime minister.
One Tshisekedi adviser told Reuters UDPS leaders were meeting over Friday night's incident.

"The UDPS leaders are currently meeting. A decision will be made, but let's wait and see," Mukendi Wa Mulumba said, adding: "Last night, about 50 party members were arrested. But I don't know if by now they have been released."
Kabila has granted himself sweeping powers as president and has imposed a blanket ban on political activity.
Opposition protests staged in defiance of the ban have been broken up by troops, and a demonstrator was shot dead in such a march last month.
